cmes.note: This CME is visible to the north in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery in real-time due to a data gap starting at 2026-01-14T16:23Z. The source may be related to an eruption and C3.8 flare from Active Region 14340 (N15E05) starting around 2026-01-14T23:40Z as seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193/304 and GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 imagery. Dimming is observed near the eruption site in SDO AIA 193 and GOES SUVI 195 imagery. A subsequent EUV wave is observed traveling northwest of the eruption site. Noting that a coronal hole located southeast of Active Region 14340 may be responsible for northwestern deflection of this CME. The start of the CME is covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 coronagraph and after the data gap its front is very fuzzy/faint in COR2 coronagraph. The CME is also partially obscured by the pylon in STEREO LASCO C3.

cmeAnalyses.note: Final but somewhat approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO and STEREO A COR2) and confirmed by the location of the likely source (C-class flare in AR 14340 (N15E05)). The CME front is very fuzzy in STEREO A COR2 coronagraph, as most of its propagation is covered by a large daily data gap in STEREO A. The CME is also partially obscured by the pylon in STEREO LASCO C3.

Very preliminary measurement made with one coronagraph (SOHO LASCO) based on the source longitude. The measured parameters are speculative as this measurement relies on early imagery. Additionally, a triangulated measurement is not available due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: Complex-shaped, bright halo CME with multiple (up to 3) fronts and a wide faint shock. Seen to NNW in SOHO LASCO/GOES CCOR-1 and to the NW in STEREO A COR2. Far-sided high N latitude source is clearly indicated by significant movement of field line in SDO AIA 171 to the NW starting after 2026-01-15T01:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit of two main lobes of this complex-shaped CME in two coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO and STEREO A COR2).

cmes.note: CME with a wide faint shock and narrow bright bulk to the NE in SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1 and to the N or NNE in STEREO A COR2. The initially bright bulk soon becomes faint after a couple of SOHO LASCO C2 timestamps. The source is likely the long two-pronged prominence seen to the NE in GOES SUVI 304 after approximately 2026-01-15T07:00Z. The prominence is likely obscured in SDO AIA 304 in two bad (all dark) images.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis of this far-sided CME made with the fit in two coronagraphs (STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO). The source (filament eruption) is behind the NE limb.
SHOCK measurement based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the North by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-15T23:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This CME is not currently visible in STEREO A COR2 due to an ongoing data gap beginning at 2026-01-15T16:23Z. The source of this event is a filament eruption seen in SDO AIA and GOES SUVI 304 centered at approximately N55W30 with liftoff beginning at approx. 2026-01-15T22:06Z. It appears a majority of this material fell back down, but some fully erupted.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east in STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is not observed in real-time by SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to a planned data gap between downlink periods. The source is an eruption and C6.6 flare from Active Region 14345 (S17E58) starting around 2026-01-16T09:00Z seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193/304 and GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 imagery. An opening of field lines is visible over the southeast limb around this time as seen in SDO AIA 193, GOES SUVI 195/284, and STEREO A EUVI 195 imagery. Due to a coronal hole located west of the source location, the resulting CME exhibits eastern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery.

cmes.note: Thin jet-like CME observed to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1, not in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. This CME is much less than 10 degrees half width. The source appears to be AR 14336 (S09W87), as the observed filament ejecta in SDO AIA 171/304 starting around 2026-01-16T23:22Z starts near AR 14336 but sharply deflects NW then W along curved field lines.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C2 only plane of sky due to heavy deflection from the source and no STEREO A COR2 to triangulate. CME half width is much less than 10 degrees, likely around 3-5 degrees maximum, limited analysis by the swpc_cat tool.

cmes.note: Jet-like CME visible to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source appears to be a C4.7 flare from AR 14336 just on/beyond the western limb in SDO/AIA 304 starting around 2026-01-17T02:22Z. The filament eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUVI 304 with possible deflection to the W due to a nearby coronal hole.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 with a faint, fuzzy front overlapping with/following preceding faint outflow. The source could be one in a series of filament eruptions extending from AR 14341 (approximately S11E30) to AR 14342 (approximately N17E40) with filament liftoff and brightening seen in SDO AIA 304 starting at 2026-01-17T02:39Z. An alternate source is the opening/moving field lines seen on the NE limb in GOES SUVI 284 between 2026-01-17T05:00Z and 2026-01-17T10:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis of an extremely fuzzy front in two coronagraphs (STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2). There seems to be eastern deflection of over 10 degrees, as the likely source eruption has the longitude of ~40 degrees.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is a filament eruption visible in all SDO/AIA wavelengths, in GOES SUVI wavelengths (including 304 and 284), and in STEREO A EUVI 304 and 195 starting around 2026-01-17T04:45Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is a small coronal hole to the east of the eruption location which may have caused deflection of the CME within the field of view.

cmes.note: Fuzzy front seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C3/C2 and GOES CCOR-1 and to the SW in STEREO A COR2. In C2 there is a couple of consecutive fronts seen, with the later one catching up with the earlier one, so it is not easy to identify the start of the CME. No source has been found for this CME, so it is likely far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very speculative, approximate analysis based on the fit of this faint, fuzzy front with two coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO and STEREO A COR2). The source is likely far-sided and no coronal signatures have been found in EUV imagery.

cmes.note: CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1. The source may be one of a series of filament eruptions extending from AR 14341 to AR 14342, centered around N10E40. One of these eruptions can be starting at 2026-01-17T07:34Z in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis of an extremely fuzzy front in two coronagraphs (STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2). There seems to be eastern deflection of over 10 degrees, as the likely source eruption has the longitude of ~40 degrees.

cmes.note: CME seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1. The potential source may be one of a series of filament eruptions extending from AR 14341 to AR 14342, with a filament liftoff starting around 2026-01-17T10:22Z as seen in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis of an extremely fuzzy front in two coronagraphs (STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2). There seems to be eastern deflection of over 10 degrees, as the likely source eruption has the longitude of ~40 degrees.

cmes.note: Narrow jet-like CME seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 and not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a daily data gap. Its source could be the narrow minor prominence off or from behind the west limb seen at 2026-01-17T23:06Z in GOES SUVI 304 (and in SDO AIA 304).

cmeAnalyses.note: The CME is not seen in STEREO A COR2 coronagraph and its source is either on or behind the west limb, so no triangulation is possible.

cmes.note: Faint CME first seen to the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-18T01:36Z. This CME fades before exiting the C2 field-of-view, and is therefore not visible in SOHO LASCO C33, STEREO A COR2 or GOES CCOR-1. The source of this event is an eruption from AR 14341 (S11E29) seen beginning at 2026-01-17T22:55Z, exhibiting very strong Northern deflection in SDO AIA 193 and 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2.

cmes.note: Narrow CME first seen to the West by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-18T08:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. There is not clear source seen for this event as it is likely far sided, but is not clearly seen in STEREO A EUVI imagery either.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C2, SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the Northeast in STEREO A COR2 beginning at 2026-01-18T09:38Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The source of this event is an eruption from AR 14341 (S11E24) beginning at approx. 2026-01-18T07:55Z. This eruption is seen as dimming and field line opening seen in SDO AIA 193, 211, 304 and STEREO A EUVI 195 exhibiting a strong Northern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Halo CME first seen to the East by STEREO A COR2 beginning at 2026-01-18T18:09Z, as well as by GOES CCOR-1 as a halo in later frames. This CME was initially covered by a routine scheduled downlink data gap in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 which began at 2026-01-18T18:00Z but LASCO data became fully available later. The source of this CME is a long duration X1.9 flare from Active Region 14341 (S15E20), which peaked at 2026-01-18T18:09Z, with some possible contribution from Active Region 14345 (S16E27). This flare is visible in SDO AIA 94 and 131 and the associated eruption is seen as a wide region of dimming and field line opening in SDO AIA 193, 211 and GOES SUVI 284, as well as very high and large area post eruptive arcades seen in SDO AIA 94, 304 and 193. Ejecta is seen in SDO AIA 193 and in STEREO A EUV 304 imagery (southwardly directed off the SE limb as seen from STEREO A). STEREO A 195 also sees it as a large opening of field lines close to the limb, around the equator.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis of the wide faint shock front based on the fit with two coronagraphs (STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1) in the absence of SOHO LASCO imagery that is expected to be available later.

Approximate analysis based on the fit with all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1) and on the location of the flare, made once SOHO LASCO imagery became available. Analysis is complicated by the CME having two overlapping lobes, one more to the SE and another a bit more central.

Very approximate early analysis based on the fit of one of at least two overlapping fronts with two coronagraphs (GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2). The CME is not yet available because of a scheduled gap in downlink, but will become available later.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. This event is not visible in real-time by STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source is likely an eruption near Active Region 14349 (S15E90) visible in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery starting around 2026-01-18T22:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source longitude.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is not observed in STEREO A COR2 imagery in real-time due to a data gap. The source is likely an eruption from Active Region 14349 (~S15E90) visible in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery starting at 2026-01-19T01:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source longitude.

cmes.note: This event is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery in real-time due to a data gap. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is uncertain but may be related to a minor eruption from Active Region 14351 (S04E61) starting around 2026-01-19T02:15Z as seen in SDO AIA 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source for this event is unknown as there are no clear source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the north/northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no clear source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption near Active Region 14349 (~S15E80) visible in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 304 imagery starting around 2026-01-19T06:20Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is not clearly seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source for this event is uncertain and likely far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the uncertain source location.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source for this event is unknown and may be far-sided as there are no clear source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east in GOES CCOR-1 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. This event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2026-01-19T18:38Z. The source for this event is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

cmes.note: Faint, narrow CME first seen to the East in SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-20T06:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The source of this event is a C2.1 class flare which peaked at 2026-01-20T05:32Z from Active Region 14349 (S10E70) as seen in SDO AIA 131. Field line opening and a small amount of filament material can be seen in association with this flare in SDO AIA 193 and 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: Narrow CME seen to the North by GOES CCOR-1 beginning at 2026-01-20T06:45Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. There is no clear source seen for this event as it likely originated from near/beyond the limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement due to unclear source location near the North limb. Measurement based on best fit in GOES CCOR-1 and SOHO LASCO C3.

cmes.note: Faint CME first seen to the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-20T08:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The source of this event is a very minor eruption seen in GOES SUVI 195 beginning at approx. 2026-01-20T07:22Z, located near Active Region 14349 (S14E68).

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the South by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-20T09:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This event is obscured by the pylon in GOES CCOR-1. The source of this CME is a slow erupting filament seen along the South limb in SDO AIA and GOES SUVI 304 and is seen to the SW in STEREO A EUVI 304, suggesting a far sided source location. This filament begins to lift off at approx. 2026-01-20T07:28Z, but does not appear to leave the disk at approx. 2026-01-20T09:04Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: Narrow CME seen to the North by STEREO A COR2 beginning at 2026-01-20T12:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. There is no clear source seen for this event as it likely originated from near/beyond the limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit in GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the NE in GOES CCOR-1 starting at 2026-01-21T00:15Z. In real time, this CME was only seen in GOES CCOR-1 and was missed by SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 due to real-time data gaps. The source of this CME is most likely far-sided. There is some field line movement from on/beyond the NE limb best seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting as early as 2026-01-20T22:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement based on running difference imagery from GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the west in GOES CCOR-1, SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is a data gap in SOHO LASCO imagery in real-time from 2026-01-21T08:24Z to 11:24Z. As such, the earliest frame of this event is not observed by SOHO LASCO imagery and this CME is only seen in SOHO LASCO coronagraphs following the data gap at 2026-01-21T11:24Z. The source for this event is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is blocked by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3 and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap starting at 2026-01-21T16:08Z. The source may be related to dimming centered near N08W45 seen in SDO AIA 193 imagery starting around 2026-01-21T16:00Z but the source is unclear.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees due to the uncertain source and data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: CME visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1. Not seen in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C3 in real-time due to a data gap. The source may be an eruption centered around N15W55, best seen as dimming starting at 2026-01-21T16:00Z in GOES SUVI 195. The eruption is not clearly visible in SDO imagery due to a spacecraft maneuver.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the potential source location using GOES CCOR-1 imagery.
